questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for follow-up examination 5 days after sustaining a forehead laceration. Examination shows a linear, well-approximated laceration over the right temple. The wound is clean and dry with no exudate. There is a small amount of pink granulation tissue present. Microscopic examination of the wound is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Angiogenesis with type III collagen deposition
Macrophage infiltration and fibrin clot degradation
Capillary dilation with neutrophilic migration
Acellular tissue with type I collagen deposition
Fibroblast hyperplasia with disorganized collagen deposition

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Microscopic examination of this boy's wound is most likely to show granulation tissue, which is characterized by angiogenesis (driven by secretion of VEGF, EGF, TGF-β, and PDGF) with type III collagen deposition. There are 4 phases of wound healing: the exudative, resorptive, proliferative, and maturation phases. The proliferative phase (3–7 days) is characterized by the presence of fibroblasts, endothelial cells, keratinocytes, macrophages, and myofibroblasts, which cause wound contraction.
Image Description:

Granulation tissue develops during the proliferative stage. It consists of macrophages, fibroblasts, and lymphocytes. Granulation tissue is abundant in blood capillaries and type 3 collagen fibers. Epidermal stem cells at the wound margins proliferate to renew the epidermis at the wound site. Secretion of collagenase facilitates clot degradation. Wound contraction occurs as collagen synthesis increases and pulls the wound edges together. This process is facilitated by myofibroblasts.

B) INCORRECT:

Macrophage infiltration and fibrin clot degradation does not occur in the proliferative phase (days 3–7) but is seen in the late resorptive phase (day 2) of wound healing. During this time, macrophages migrate into the wound and degrade the hematoma, and the epithelium at the wound margins begins to proliferate.
Image Description:

Macrophages release growth factors and cytokines that recruit other immune cells and stimulate fibroblast proliferation. Lymphocytes promote cellular immunity, and neutrophils and macrophages phagocytose pathogens and cellular debris.

C) INCORRECT:

Capillary dilation with neutrophilic migration does not occur in the proliferative phase (days 3–7) but is seen in the early resorptive phase (day 1) of wound healing. During this time, macrophages release growth factors and cytokines that recruit other immune cells (i.e., neutrophils) and stimulate fibroblast proliferation.

D) INCORRECT:

Acellular tissue with type I collagen deposition does not occur in the proliferative phase (days 3–7) but is seen in the maturation phase of wound healing, which takes place weeks after the injury. During this time, the proliferation of fibroblasts causes a scar to form and remodeling of connective tissue as well as removal of excess collagen also occurs.
Image Description:

Scar tissue formation occurs as type I collagen replaces type III collagen in the connective tissue. The scar tissue is covered by epidermis, but it lacks melanocytes and skin appendages such as hair follicles or cutaneous sweat glands.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibroblast hyperplasia with disorganized collagen deposition does not occur in the proliferative phase (days 3–7) but is seen in keloids, which usually first start forming 3–12 months after an injury. Keloids are caused by dysregulation of the wound healing process during the proliferative and maturation stages, which causes excess fibroblast proliferation and collagen deposition.
questions.hint: This boy’s laceration, which has been allowed to heal by primary intention, is in the proliferative phase of wound healing.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician 6 months after delivering a baby by lower segment transverse cesarean section. She is worried about the appearance of her cesarean section scar. Examination shows a linear, erythematous, raised suprapubic scar, confined within the original wound margins. Biopsy of the scar shows dense collagen fibers organized parallel to the surface of the epidermis. An increase in the production of which of the following mediators is most likely responsible for the changes seen in this patient's scar?

choices.text: Platelet-activating factor
Tumor necrosis factor-alpha
Interleukin 10
Transforming growth factor-beta
Thromboxane A2
Matrix metalloproteinase-3

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Platelet-activating factor (PAF) leads to platelet aggregation and chemotaxis of leukocytes (e.g., neutrophils, macrophages) to the site of injury, and it is involved in the inflammatory (exudative) phase of wound healing, which occurs 1–3 days after injury. The elapsed time and changes in this patient's scar are consistent with the maturation phase of wound healing; PAF is not increased during this phase.

B) INCORRECT:

Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) is a proinflammatory cytokine secreted primarily during the inflammatory phase of wound healing (days 1–3 following the initial injury). The role of TNF-α on the maturation phase of wound healing and collagen deposition (fibrosis) is less clear; recent studies show that hypertrophic scars contain lower amounts of TNF-α than normal scars. The increase in production of a different cytokine is primarily involved in fibrosis and hypertrophic scar formation.

C) INCORRECT:

Interleukin-10 (IL-10) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that decreases rather than increases collagen deposition and thereby prevents hypertrophic scar formation. An increase in the production of a different anti-inflammatory cytokine and certain proinflammatory interleukins (e.g., IL-6) is implicated in the pathogenesis of hypertrophic scars.

D) CORRECT:

The pathogenesis of excessive scar tissue (e.g., hypertrophic scar, keloid) involves an excessive production of certain isoforms of transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β) at the site of injury when compared with normal wound healing. These TGF-β isoforms increase angiogenesis during the proliferative phase of wound healing and increase fibroblast proliferation and collagen deposition during the maturation phase of wound healing. TGF-β also prevents collagen breakdown by decreasing the activity of metalloproteinases (e.g., collagenase) and upregulating tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinase. Excessive production of platelet-derived growth factor and connective tissue growth factor are also implicated in excessive scar tissue formation.

E) INCORRECT:

Thromboxane A2 (TXA2), which is released from platelets and endothelial cells, causes vasoconstriction and platelet aggregation. This mediator is involved in the first phase of wound healing (i.e., hemostasis or exudative phase), which occurs 5–10 minutes after the initial injury. The elapsed time and changes in this patient's wound are consistent with the maturation phase of wound healing; TXA2 is not involved during this phase.

F) INCORRECT:

Matrix metalloproteinase-3 (MMP-3) is released by fibroblasts and proliferating keratinocytes and is active during the maturation phase of wound healing, which is the phase seen here. However, matrix metalloproteinases such as MMP-3 break down components of the extracellular matrix such as collagen; a decrease rather than increase in the production of MMPs is implicated in the pathogenesis of scar hypertrophy.
questions.hint: A linear, erythematous, raised scar confined within the original margins of the wound is suggestive of a hypertrophic scar, which results from fibroblast proliferation and excessive deposition of extracellular matrix (typically collagen) during the maturation phase of wound healing. Certain isoforms of this mediator have an anti-inflammatory effect and are produced by activated Treg cells.

questions.text: Three days after delivering a healthy newborn via an uncomplicated, scheduled cesarean delivery, a 31-year-old woman is evaluated on the ward because of pain around the incision area. The pain worsens when she changes from supine to seated position to breastfeed her newborn. During the wound closure, one drain was placed in the subcutaneous space. Medical history is unremarkable. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 118/80 mm Hg. Physical examination of the suprapubic area shows a transverse, 13-cm, dry incision wound with closely adapted margins. There is mild tenderness and erythema extending 1 cm around the incision site with minimal swelling, but no discharge. The drain collects serous fluid. The abdomen is soft without guarding or rebound. Her hemoglobin concentration is 13.4 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8400/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 20 mm/h. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Cover the wound with a moist dressing and plan surgical revision
Prescribe acetaminophen and reassure the patient
Obtain a wound swab and start intravenous cefazolin
Perform ultrasound of the lower abdomen and suprapubic region
Apply topical mupirocin and aseptic wound dressing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Covering the wound with a moist dressing and planning for surgical revision is indicated in patients with early fascial dehiscence at the incision site, which can occur after any type of abdominal surgery. However, fascial dehiscence typically manifests 4–14 days after surgery and is characterized by profuse serosanguinous drainage, a “popping” sensation, or bulge during Valsalva maneuvers.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's surgical wound is healing by primary intention (primary wound closure), which occurs in 4 phases (see “Phases of wound healing” table). The first 3 phases (exudative, resorptive, proliferative) occur over approx. 1 week and the last phase (maturation) proceeds over weeks to months. During the resorptive phase, vasodilation occurs due to the release of cytokines and growth factors (e.g., PDGF, TGF-β) by inflammatory cells, which leads to mild tenderness and redness. A slight increase in leukocyte count and inflammatory markers may also occur after surgery.

In the absence of features suggestive of surgical site infection (i.e., severe tenderness, erythema and induration that expands rapidly from the incision site or extends > 5 cm from the wound edge, fever > 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate > 110/min, WBC count > 12,000 cells/mm3), conservative management and reassurance are sufficient. Conservative management includes analgesia with acetaminophen (which is also safe during breastfeeding), local application of ice or warm compresses, and keeping the wound site clean and dry.

C) INCORRECT:

A wound swab and IV cefazolin are indicated when surgical site infection (SSI) is suspected, i.e., for patients with erythema and induration that expands rapidly or extends > 5 cm from the wound edge, fever > 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate > 110/min, and/or a WBC count > 12,000 cells/mm3. Moreover, SSIs typically occur > 4 days following the procedure; SSIs during the first 4 days can occur as a result of Group A streptococcus or Clostridium perfringens infection but are uncommon.

D) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound of the lower abdomen and suprapubic region can be used to assess for a seroma or hematoma, which can manifest a few days after surgery with localized pain or drainage of fluids. However, mild pain around an incision site and a dry, well-approximated wound without severe swelling do not suggest a seroma/hematoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Aseptic wound dressing should be used for all surgical wounds and topical mupirocin is indicated in patients with superficial skin infections. Although mild redness and tenderness can occur with superficial skin infections, other characteristic features of infection, such as fever, localized warmth, induration, and pus at the incision site, would also be expected in this patient.
questions.hint: Pain around an incision site with mild redness and swelling three days after cesarean delivery indicates a wound that is healing by primary intention.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 1 month after sustaining a chemical burn over the dorsum of his right hand and forearm. Physical examination shows hyperextension of the hand at the wrist. The skin over the dorsum of the wrist is tense and there is a thick, epithelialized scar. Range of motion of the right wrist is restricted. This patient's contracture is most likely due to activity of which of the following cells?

choices.text: Neutrophils
Macrophages
Fibroblasts
Endothelial cells
Myofibroblasts

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neutrophils are observed during the early inflammatory stage of wound healing (days 1–3). They help digest bacteria, foreign debris, and necrotic tissue by secreting lysosomal enzymes. Neutrophils are not involved in wound contraction.

B) INCORRECT:

Macrophages, which are mainly derived from recruited monocytes, are observed in the inflammatory (days 1–3) and proliferative (days 3–7) stages of wound healing. They assist in host defense, removal of apoptotic cells, and promotion of cellular proliferation and angiogenesis by secreting cytokines such as VEGF. However, macrophages are not involved in wound contraction.

C) INCORRECT:

Fibroblasts are derived from the local mesenchymal stem cells or migrate from the nearby dermis to the wound in response to cytokines and growth factors (e.g., TGF-β) secreted by platelets and macrophages in the wound. They produce collagen and other components of the extracellular matrix and therefore play an important role during the resorptive stage (days 1–3), proliferative stage (formation of granulation tissue; days 3–7) and maturation phase (scar formation and remodeling of connective tissue; 1 week to 1 year) of the wound healing process. However, another cell type specializes in contraction of wound edges.

D) INCORRECT:

Endothelial cells, together with fibroblasts, smooth muscle cells, and platelets, secrete vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), which promotes angiogenesis during the proliferative phase of wound healing. Angiogenesis during wound healing involves a series of steps, including vasodilation, basement membrane degradation, endothelial cell migration and proliferation, capillary tube formation and anastomosis, and finally basement membrane formation. However, endothelial cells are not involved in wound contraction.

E) CORRECT:

Myofibroblasts, derived from fibroblasts, generate a contractile force that draws wound edges together. They are present in the proliferative stage of wound healing (days 3–7) and are lost through apoptosis when wound healing is complete. However, excessive proliferation and persistence of myofibroblasts lead to pathologic fibrosis and contracture, which causes functional impairment, as is the case here.

See “Phases of wound healing” table.
Image Description:

Granulation tissue develops during the proliferative stage. It consists of macrophages, fibroblasts, and lymphocytes. Granulation tissue is abundant in blood capillaries and type 3 collagen fibers. Epidermal stem cells at the wound margins proliferate to renew the epidermis at the wound site. Secretion of collagenase facilitates clot degradation. Wound contraction occurs as collagen synthesis increases and pulls the wound edges together. This process is facilitated by myofibroblasts.
questions.hint: Wound contraction occurs during the proliferative phase of wound healing. This process is not only facilitated by a special cell type but is also mediated by metalloproteinase secretion.
